As a designer, I’m specialized in creating enterprise SaaS products, or as I like to say at parties: I make tools for people at work1. Somewhere on my design journey I fell in love with the complexity, and usability challenges of the software professionals use to do their job.

I’ve learnt plenty about this field in the seven years that I’ve been specializing in it. Here are some characteristics of Enterprise SaaS with which I have personal experience:

  • Buyer ≠ user
  • Tactical UX design is crucial: I believe firmly in the idea that, as a designer, you should Design what you need, and I’ve learnt that enterprise UX in particular benefits from this.
  • There’s leeway in UX, and imperfections don’t make you lose clients right away
  • Complexity is leitmotif
  • Few competitors, slow decision-making
  • Challenging stakeholder management
  • Users are comfortable with suboptimal legacy solutions

Further reading

  • UX Matters, “Defining Enterprise UX”, 2018-09-24

  1. I borrow this term from “Defining Enterprise UX” by UXmatters, an important resource for me. ↩
